Growing up, I was always told to be a good son. To study hard, to get good grades, to get a good job. To marry a good woman, to have good children, to be a good father. To be a good son, I had to suppress my own desires, my own needs, my own dreams.

I wanted to be an artist, to paint and draw and create. But my parents wanted me to be a doctor, to be a lawyer, to be a businessman. They wanted me to be successful, to be wealthy, to be respected.

So I put my dreams aside, and I studied hard. I got good grades, I got a good job, I got married to a good woman. But I was miserable. I was trapped in a life that wasn't mine, a life that I didn't want.

And then I had children of my own. And I realized that I was repeating the same cycle. I was passing on the same expectations, the same pressures, the same sacrifices to my own children.

But I didn't want that for them. I wanted them to be free, to be able to pursue their own dreams, their own desires. I wanted them to be happy, to be fulfilled.

So I made a change. I started to pursue my own dreams, my own passions. I started to paint and draw again, to create and express myself. And it was liberating.

It was hard, of course. It was scary, it was uncertain. But it was worth it. Because I was finally being true to myself, finally being the person I was meant to be.

And I hope that my children will learn from my example. I hope that they will be brave enough to pursue their own dreams, to follow their own hearts. I hope that they will be free, to be themselves, to be happy.

It's hard being a Southeast Asian son. But it's not impossible. And it's not worth it. Because being true to yourself, being free to be yourself, is the greatest gift of all.
